stream_context.summary: Kaze announces a new TeePublic merch store (starting with course-themed shirts), then returns to integrating Biobak’s latest Course 10 (C10) rework: importing updated actors/assets, debugging Fast64/Blender export issues, tuning materials/colors, fixing a Yoshi model/interaction regression, and starting a new collision map after major layout shifts. Along the way he explains deep engine optimization decisions (actor ordering for instruction cache locality) and mentions F3 2025 plans as a sponsored event with a potential cash-prize vote.
stream_context.significance_reason: Contains meaningful documentary-relevant reveals: Kaze’s unusually low-level performance philosophy (instruction-cache-driven actor ordering), a concrete business/community initiative (TeePublic merch + sponsored F3 2025 with cash reward), and several representative pipeline problems (Fast64 material constraints, Blender version quirks, N64-only rendering edge cases) while integrating Biobak’s C10 update.

findings.summary: Kaze launches a new merch storefront on TeePublic (cheaper than Spreadshirt) but notes YouTube Studio integration can take up to two days; the first designs include a Course 4 shirt and Rambos items, with a plan to produce a design for every course using the final in-game course icons.

While pulling Biobak’s updated changelog and exports, Kaze hits a recurring Fast64/texture constraint error (“texture has too many colors”) that turns out to be caused by duplicate texture names leading to the wrong texture being used; he resolves it and proceeds with the import.

Kaze reports major internal cleanup: he fixed many “annoying” engine bugs recently, is “slowly approaching zero engine bugs,” and got the compiler to produce zero warnings—framing it as a meaningful quality milestone for the project’s codebase.
He showcases the updated C10 visuals as running at ~55 FPS and argues the project’s N64-era look is exceptionally strong, emphasizing water and overall scene quality as a selling point.

To address an N64-only visual issue, Kaze adjusts grass overhang geometry because of z-clipping; the fix is to reposition/extend overhangs so the seam effectively disappears on hardware despite being “invisible” on emulator.

Kaze explains a core engine optimization strategy: actors execute in a deterministic order based on naming; he groups same-code actors with similar names to improve cache proximity. He discusses instruction-cache behavior and claims his game loop is optimized enough that Mario’s behavior code essentially never gets evicted from I-cache under normal play.

He strongly rejects an entity-component-system approach for this project, arguing it adds overhead (“run code to figure out what to run”) and that deterministic ordering and memory layout are what matter on N64-class constraints.
findings.quote: Entity component system is complete garbage… you just need to order the actors correctly in memory.

findings.summary: Kaze clarifies the project’s lighting/texture approach: shadows are baked via vertex colors and primitive-color multiplication rather than shadow textures; he avoids environment color due to a known Fast64 issue and frames vertex lighting as strictly superior for static geometry (but it sacrifices some dynamic lighting effects).

He integrates a newer Yoshi model (implied to be Biobak’s improved version) and debugs multiple issues: missing collision/interaction, wrong object list classification, a missing animation causing a mouth-open clip, and a regression where Yoshi’s dialogue triggers twice. He patches the logic enough to re-enable entering Yoshi (“go inside the Yoshi”) and defers the double-talk bug.

Kaze notes that with F3DEX3 in the pipeline, they no longer need certain manual patching steps because patching is now automatic; he also remarks collision data is cheap enough that duplicating/mirroring collisions is acceptable when exporting mirrored geometry is annoying.

He tunes foliage/“TempoBush” visuals by adjusting primitive-color brightness/variance and placement (down into the floor for better animation), balancing readability (avoid too bright) against variation, while taking feedback about outlines and saturation.
Kaze announces F3 2025 will happen this year and—because it’s sponsored—he’s considering a user vote where the most popular game receives a cash reward on release as added motivation.

biobak.summary: Biobak delivers a new changelog and asset/actor updates for C10, including geometry/material changes that require reimport and on-stream tuning (colors, outlines, placement).
Biobak provides an updated Yoshi model that Kaze prefers over the old one (“what’s wrong with the old Yoshi… Biobak made a nice one”), prompting armature/tongue/animation reintegration work.

zeina.summary: Kaze mentions he’s streaming from the basement because Zeina “banished” him there; later he references Zeina’s habit of calling just a sausage a “hot dog,” illustrating their recurring playful domestic banter on stream.

findings.summary: Lilaa pushes Kaze to explain I-cache behavior and object ordering tradeoffs (e.g., repeating one actor type vs mixed actors), prompting a rare, detailed performance explanation tied to N64 constraints.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: I don’t think you can even make the case that there’s a better looking N64 game than this… anywhere in the world.
memorable_quotes.context: Said while showing the updated C10 scene (notably water) at high framerate, framing RTYI’s visuals as a marquee achievement.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: There are only two programming languages and that’s assembly and high level. And anything after that is mental illness.
memorable_quotes.context: A character-defining exaggeration while discussing C standards/ANSI and his pragmatic approach: he learns only what he needs to control compiler output and assembly.

key_stories.title: C10 import blocked by a ‘too many colors’ texture regression
key_stories.summary: While integrating Biobak’s newest C10 export, a previously-solved N64 texture limitation suddenly reappears. Kaze tracks it down to an asset pipeline gotcha—two textures sharing the same name—causing the wrong texture to be referenced and triggering the color-limit error.
key_stories.challenge: Fast64 reports a texture color-limit error that ‘should have been fixed yesterday,’ threatening the day’s planned import work.
key_stories.process: Kaze re-downloads/retries the export, inspects the unexpected texture output, hypothesizes a duplicate-name collision, and re-runs the import with corrected references.
key_stories.outcome: The import proceeds after identifying the duplicate texture name as the culprit, allowing him to continue integrating Biobak’s changes.

key_stories.title: Yoshi breaks: missing interaction/animation and ‘talks twice’ regression
key_stories.summary: Updating to a newer Yoshi model triggers multiple gameplay-facing issues: collision/interaction doesn’t register correctly, one mouth-open animation disappears/clips, and Yoshi’s dialogue triggers twice. Kaze prioritizes getting ‘enter Yoshi’ working again so the level remains playable, then defers the deeper behavioral regression.
key_stories.challenge: The new Yoshi asset appears in the wrong state (no collision/interaction), and a missing animation/flag logic issue prevents intended gameplay flow (including ‘go inside the Yoshi’ section).
key_stories.process: Kaze checks object list classification (predicting it will show ‘OBJ list spawner’ vs ‘surface’), edits model/armature assignments, identifies the missing animation, and simplifies/removes legacy cutscene flags he believes are obsolete from an older engine version.
key_stories.outcome: He restores functionality enough to enter Yoshi and continue level work, but leaves the “talks twice” issue for later investigation.
key_stories.key_quote: I knew it. He’s fixed… I still don’t see how I can talk twice to you.

key_stories.title: Collision rebuild after layout shifts (and mirroring pain)
key_stories.summary: Because ‘everything moved’ in the updated course layout (including warp holes), Kaze has to rebuild collision to keep the reworked area playable. He also discovers mirrored geometry/collision can’t be solved with a simple negative scale, deciding that exporting two collisions is acceptable since collision data is cheap.
key_stories.challenge: Major asset movement invalidates existing collision; mirrored sections complicate reuse and exporter constraints block simple mirroring tricks.
key_stories.process: Kaze trims unnecessary triangles where possible, searches for the relevant collapse-floor model, tests collision assumptions, and plans to export separate collision sets rather than fight mirroring limitations.
key_stories.outcome: He begins collision authoring but decides to finish the bulk of the collision work off-stream due to time and tedium.

open_questions.topic: Actor ordering as a first-class optimization strategy
open_questions.context: Kaze claims a measurable performance win by ordering actors by name (thus execution order) to improve instruction-cache locality, and says Mario’s behavior loop effectively never leaves I-cache in his optimized build.
questions: When did you first realize actor ordering could be used as a systemic performance tool—not just micro-optimization—and what experiment convinced you it was worth redesigning around?
How did this constraint (cache locality via naming/order) change how you and level designers (like Biobak) structure actor placement and naming conventions in practice?
What tradeoffs did you accept (tooling complexity, designer friction, debugging difficulty) to keep this deterministic, cache-friendly ordering?

open_questions.topic: Fast64 pipeline constraints shaping rendering choices (primitive vs environment color)
open_questions.context: Kaze says environment color is disabled because of a Fast64 issue, pushing them toward primitive color and vertex-color lighting; he positions it as superior for static geometry but with lost dynamic-light effects.
questions: What exactly is the Fast64 environment-color failure mode you hit, and how did it change your material conventions across the whole project?
How often do tool limitations like this force you to redesign art direction decisions—and how do you communicate those ‘engine rules’ to collaborators so assets don’t come back incompatible?

open_questions.topic: F3 2025 sponsorship and a cash-prize ‘release day’ vote
open_questions.context: Kaze proposes a sponsored F3 2025 with a user vote where the most popular game gets a cash reward upon release, positioning it as extra motivation.
questions: What’s the origin story of F3 2025 being sponsored this year—who approached whom, and what changed compared to past years?
How would you structure a user-vote cash reward so it motivates developers without turning F3 into a popularity contest or encouraging rushed releases?
